ch.ecma.csta.physical

Interface PhysicalDeviceListener

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.EventListener
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    PhysicalDeviceAdapter

    public interface PhysicalDeviceListener
extends java.util.EventListener
    Initiates an event monitor on the physical element of a specified device. The supported CSTA events include:
    • DisplayUpdatedEvent
    • LampModeEvent
    • RingerStatusEvent
    • E911CallBlockedEvent
    • HookswitchEvent
    • ServiceLinkStatusEvent
    • MessageWaitingEvent

    Note that not all of the parameters for any given event may be supported. In these cases, the event description will contain a table of the parameters that are supported.

    Java listeners are used to implement the CSTA concept called monitoring. Add a listener to a device using the MonitoringServices.addPhysicalDeviceListener method. Adding a listener to a device is equivalent to requesting a Monitor Start service for that device. To learn more about using listeners with this API, see Using Listeners in the Device, Media & Call Control (DMCC) API.

    Version:
    $Revision: 1.4 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.

    • Method Detail

      • buttonInformationChanged

        void buttonInformationChanged(ButtonInformationEvent event)
        Not implemented.

      • buttonPressed

        void buttonPressed(ButtonPressEvent event)
        Not implemented.

      • displayUpdated

        void displayUpdated(DisplayUpdatedEvent event)
        A callback function which is automatically invoked when the DisplayUpdatedEvent occurs on that device and this listener has been added to a device. The DisplayUpdatedEvent occurs if the contents of a device's display has changed. See the DisplayUpdatedEvent for more information.

        The device parameter of the DisplayUpdatedEvent structure is of type is SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();
        Parameters:
        event - describes the display and its current contents

      • hookswitchChanged

        void hookswitchChanged(HookswitchEvent event)
        Indicates that the switch has changed the device's hookswitch status. This event is not sent if your device explicitly goes onhook with a SetHookswitchStatus request. It only occurs when all other parties on the call drop or are dropped. The switch then automatically sets the device's hookswitch status to on hook.

      • lampUpdated

        void lampUpdated(LampModeEvent event)
        A callback function which is automatically invoked when the LampUpdatedEvent occurs on that device and this listener has been added to a device. The LampUpdatedEvent occurs if the lamp mode status of a particular lamp has changed. See the LampModeEvent for more information.

        The device parameter is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();

        The complete set of possible values for the LampMode parameter specific to Communication Manager is:

        • LampModeConstants.BROKENFLUTTER
        • LampModeConstants.FLASH
        • LampModeConstants.FLUTTER
        • LampModeConstants.INVERTEDFLASH
        • LampModeConstants.INVERTEDWINK
        • LampModeConstants.OFF
        • LampModeConstants.STEADY
        • LampModeConstants.WINK
        * The complete set of possible values for the lampColor parameter specific to Communication Manager is:
        • LampModeConstants.RED
        • LampModeConstants.GREEN

         if(event.getLampMode().intValue() == LampModeConstants.STEADY.getID()) {
   System.out.println(event.getLamp() + " is Steady");
 }
        Parameters:
        event - describes the lamp mode status. Includes lamp label, how the lamp is lit (flutter, steady, etc.), and color.

      • messageWaitingChanged

        void messageWaitingChanged(MessageWaitingEvent event)
        Supported in a future release.

        A callback function which is automatically invoked when the MessageWaitingEvent occurs on that device and this listener has been added to a device. The MessageWaitingEvent occurs if the message waiting status has changed at the device. See the MessageWaitingEvent for more information.

        The device parameter of the MessageWaitingEvent structure is of type is SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();
        Parameters:
        event - the message waiting status has changed at the device

      • microphoneGainSettingChanged

        void microphoneGainSettingChanged(MicrophoneGainEvent event)
        Not implemented.

      • microphoneMuteStatusChanged

        void microphoneMuteStatusChanged(MicrophoneMuteEvent event)
        Not implemented.

      • ringerStatusUpdated

        void ringerStatusUpdated(RingerStatusEvent event)
        A callback function which is automatically invoked when the RingerStatusEvent occurs on that device and this listener has been added to a device. The RingerStatusEvent occurs if the ringer attribute associated with a device has changed status. See the RingerStatusEvent for more information.

        The device parameter is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();

        The complete set of possible values for the RingMode parameter specific to Communication Manager is:

        • RingMode.RINGING - The ringer is ringing (provided when either the ringer is physically ringing or is in the quiet phase of a ring cycle)
        • RingMode.NOTRINGING - The ringer is not being rung.
        The complete of possible values for the ringing pattern parameter is found in RingerPatternConstants.

        Here is an example of how to extract information from the RingerStatusEvent structure: 

         if (RingMode.RINGING.equals(event.getRingMode())) {
     Long pattern = event.getRingPattern();
     if (RingerPatternConstants.ATTENDANT_EMERGENCY.getID().equals(pattern)) {
       System.out.println("Ringing with ATTENDANT_EMERGENCY pattern.");
     }
   }
        Parameters:
        event - describes the ringer status. Includes ringing or not ringing and ring pattern.

      • serviceLinkStatusChanged

        void serviceLinkStatusChanged(ServiceLinkStatusEvent event)
        A callback function which is automatically invoked when the ServiceLinkStatusEvent occurs on that device and this listener has been added to a device. It only occurs when the terminal registers in TELECOMMUTER mode during the terminal registration. See the ServiceLinkStatusEvent for more information.

        The device parameter is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();

        Parameters:
        event - describes the service link status

      • speakerMuteStatusChanged

        void speakerMuteStatusChanged(SpeakerMuteEvent event)
        Not implemented.

      • speakerVolumeSettingChanged

        void speakerVolumeSettingChanged(SpeakerVolumeEvent event)
        Not implemented.

      • e911CallBlocked

        void e911CallBlocked(E911CallBlockedEvent event)
        Indicates that the switch has blocked the E911 emergency call request. It only occurs when an emergency call was placed from a terminal registered in TELECOMMUTER mode with a "block" option set in LoginInfo during terminal registration.

        The device parameter is of type SubjectDeviceID so extracting the device ID is a two-step process: 

         SubjectDeviceID subjDeviceID = event.getDevice();
 DeviceID deviceID = subjDeviceID.getDeviceIdentifier();

        Parameters:
        event - Indicates the E911 emergency call has been blocked.
